Climate Modeling (CMIP Protocols).perspective_relevance: My expertise in climate modeling, particularly with CMIP protocols and global temperature datasets, provides a grounded understanding of how annual global temperature records are set, what anomalies might drive records, seasonal/global spatial heterogeneity, the lagged role of ENSO in annual means, and the reliability/biases of Copernicus-ECMWF versus other global records. This background is crucial for assessing whether 2025's anomalies are enough to exceed 2024's historic global warmth, and for evaluating the impact of short-term versus long-term climate drivers.
Climate Modeling (CMIP Protocols).status_quo: 2024 is currently the warmest year on record globally, with 2023 preceding it. Most years in the past decade have been among the top 10, but consecutive 'warmest' records are uncommon and usually associated with major El Niño years. With El Niño waning in 2025, the most likely status quo outcome is that 2025 will be very warm, but not a new record.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: El Niño to Neutral/La Niña Transition
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The El Niño that drove record warmth in 2023-2024 has ended or is ending; 2025 is neutral or possibly tips toward La Niña later in the year—a regime that typically reduces global means modestly (~0.05–0.2°C) compared with strong El Niño. Since annual records are usually set during/just after major El Niño, this cycle shift makes a new record less probable without other amplifying factors.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate/Historical Precedent
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. No more than two consecutive 'warmest' years have occurred in recent ECMWF/Copernicus records (typically one to two in a row before a plateau or minor dip). 2025 would be the third, which is rare unless driven by an extended El Niño.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Marine Heatwaves/SST Anomalies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability. News reports indicate record-breaking summer marine heatwaves in the North Sea, Mediterranean, NE Atlantic, and high ocean surface temperatures, which have proven surprisingly persistent since mid-2023, potentially boosting the world’s mean temperature even without a strong ENSO event. Oceanic inertia could blunt the cooling effects of a neutral Pacific, partially offsetting the ENSO transition.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Observed 2025 Monthly Data (to date)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly decreases. May 2025 was the 2nd warmest May on record globally, slightly below May 2024, with June–August in the top three warmest but not record-breaking (per Copernicus and NOAA). There are indications that the first half of 2025 was not on pace to break the 2024 record, and models/experts (e.g., Zeke Hausfather, BE) call a new record 'very unlikely' though not impossible, and 'virtually certain' that 2025 will be in the top three.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Continued Forcing from GHGs/high CO₂
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Human-caused warming and high CO₂ (record 420 ppm) ensure the annual baseline keeps rising, reducing the 'distance' needed to set a new record over time. Nonetheless, breaking an immediate prior-year record typically still requires an additive push from short-term variability.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Cooling in Monthly Means
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The latest Copernicus/NOAA/Berkeley data suggests early 2025 months are tracking below late 2023 and early 2024 anomalies, indicating that unless the latter part of the year is exceptionally warm, a new annual record is not likely.

Climate Modeling (CMIP Protocols).no_scenario: Following the historical norm, the termination of the strong 2023–24 El Niño results in lower global mean monthly temperatures through the latter part of 2025 (especially Q3/Q4), despite continued marine and land heatwaves. While 2025 finishes as the second or third warmest year on record, the global mean does not surpass the all-time mark set in 2024 according to Copernicus-ECMWF annual summary, and question resolves No.
Climate Modeling (CMIP Protocols).yes_scenario: Ocean heat anomalies (especially in the North Atlantic and Mediterranean) remain so extreme through Q3/Q4 that they compensate for waning ENSO, possibly compounded by unexpected Arctic warmth or a secondary warming event. The end-of-year global monthly means rise, pushing the full 2025 annual mean marginally above the 2024 record in Copernicus-ECMWF’s reckoning, and question resolves Yes.
Climate Modeling (CMIP Protocols).final_reasoning: All climate model and observational data indicate that 2025 is almost certain to be among the top three warmest years, but the base rate for a record consecutive third year (and simultaneously coinciding with a waning ENSO or onset of La Niña) is low. Historic precedent—in particular, ECMWF/C3S data—shows annual records are most likely in strong El Niño years, or their immediate wake (like 2023 and 2024), but rarely persist for a third consecutive year as ENSO flips neutral/cool. While sustained marine and land heatwaves and record-high SSTs boost probabilities, and ongoing GHG forcing ratchets up annual means year-on-year, the available monthly data through late summer 2025 does not point toward 2025 being on pace to break the 2024 record globally; most expert modelers project second or third warmest. While there is always room for surprise, and oceanic inertia could still make the difference marginal, the combined base rate, real-time data, and status quo strongly favor a No outcome. My best estimate, weighing these climate modeling-specific factors, is a probability of 15% that 2025 will be the warmest year on record globally per ECMWF.

These effects would need to cumulatively add at least 0.01–0.03°C to the final 2025 mean to surpass 2024, despite early- and mid-year data running slightly cooler than 2024. Ocean heat remains high and raises the floor, but does not offset the cooling effect expected from the current ENSO-neutral or La Niña tendencies. Ensemble spread and persistence of marine heatwaves, as well as extreme events in parts of the world, keep the probability above zero—especially given post-2015 surprises. Nonetheless, present indicators, including model ensembles and real-time data, place the odds of 2025 becoming the new record below 10%. I assign a probability of 7%, consistent with the ensemble-derived tail risk of a late-year surge above 2024, but respecting expert and status quo guidance that regression to mean and ENSO reversal lower the odds of back-to-back records.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Underlying climate system momentum and greenhouse gas concentrations
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Greenhouse gases reached another record in 2024. ECMWF Operations (ERA5 Reanalysis).no_scenario: 2025 falls just short of 2024 due to the cooling impact of fading El Niño to neutral/La Niña—global monthly temperature anomalies gradually ease through the remainder of the year, especially in boreal autumn and winter. By December, Copernicus/ERA5 data ranks 2025 as the second-warmest year on record, closely trailing 2024 (e.g., by 0.02–0.05°C), as the neutral or negative ENSO state exerts a moderating influence, especially on global land and ocean anomalies.

Unanticipated regional heat spikes (e.g., over Eurasia, Africa, or the Arctic) push the global ERA5 annual mean just above the 2024 record (e.g., by 0.01–0.03°C), aided by underlying climate system inertia and high greenhouse gas concentrations.
ECMWF Operations (ERA5 Reanalysis).final_reasoning: While 2025 has featured record or near-record heat in large regions (e.g., marine heatwaves, Spain, North Africa), the most recent Copernicus and NOAA global summaries are consistent: 2025 is running closely behind 2024 but not ahead. The May–August data, representing a significant fraction of annual heat input, showed 2025 falling to 'second-warmest' for key months, breaking the extraordinary streak of 'warmest ever' months set in 2023-2024. The fading of El Niño—an important booster of global temperature records—removes the strong anomaly that helped propel 2023 and 2024 to the top. Multi-model and expert commentary (e.g., Zeke Hausfather, Copernicus leadership) state that 2025 is tracking virtually certain for a top-3 year, but the odds of a new record are rated as 'very unlikely.' However, the ongoing oceanic and regional extremity means a nontrivial probability remains that late-year anomalies could close the gap. Given all this, and weighting the base rate that record years virtually never occur in rapid succession when El Niño fades strongly, the best estimate is that the probability of 2025 exceeding 2024 in ERA5/ECMWF ranking is quite low but not zero.

Odds of 2025 being warmest are likely one-in-six to one-in-eight—a non-negligible likelihood given our climate trajectory, but bounded by both base rates and the observed 2025 data thus far.

However, due to the recent unprecedented streak and non-stationarity, the baseline is much higher than historically.

Statistics (Time Series Analysis).final_reasoning: The most relevant statistical base rate is that consecutive record-breaking years for global temperature remain rare, despite recent increases due to accelerated warming and powerful El Niño boosts.
